subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Shavian and Quikscript: legibility
msgSnippet: ... Let s try it! I went to http://shavian.weebly.com/ and flung my browser window off to the left immediately so I wouldn t be able to see the same thing
messageBody:
On Apr 20, 2013, at 1:30 AM, Michael Everson <everson@...> wrote:

> Quikscript users: Are you comfortable reading Shavian? Are you happy that, if the two are unified, that you will sometimes see Quikscript texts written with non-cursive Shavian glyphs? Think about Latin blackletter fonts, which you can and do read more or less regularly.

Let's try it!

I went to http://shavian.weebly.com/ and flung my browser window off to the left immediately so I wouldn't be able to see the same thing written in Orthodox. Here's what it says:

𐑢𐑧𐑤𐑒𐑳𐑥
𐑣𐑧𐑤𐑴 𐑯 𐑢𐑧𐑤𐑒𐑳𐑥 𐑑 𐑥𐑲 ·𐑖𐑱𐑝𐑾𐑯 𐑨𐑤𐑓𐑩𐑚𐑧𐑑 𐑢𐑧𐑚𐑕𐑲𐑑! 𐑲 𐑒𐑮𐑰𐑱𐑑𐑧𐑛 𐑞𐑦𐑕 𐑕𐑲𐑑 𐑑 𐑐𐑮𐑩𐑒𐑑𐑦𐑕 𐑮𐑲𐑑𐑦𐑙 𐑯 𐑮𐑰𐑛𐑦𐑙 𐑦𐑯 𐑞 ·𐑖𐑷 𐑕𐑒𐑮𐑦𐑐𐑑. 𐑷𐑤𐑕𐑴 𐑑 𐑖𐑺 𐑑𐑮𐑩𐑯𐑟𐑤𐑦𐑑𐑻𐑱𐑖𐑳𐑯𐑟 𐑲 𐑣𐑩𐑝 𐑥𐑱𐑛 𐑹 𐑒𐑳𐑥 𐑩𐑒𐑮𐑷𐑕. 𐑥𐑨𐑯𐑰 𐑕𐑲𐑑𐑟 𐑯 𐑮𐑧𐑕𐑹𐑕𐑧𐑟 𐑸 𐑯𐑴 𐑤𐑪𐑙𐑻 𐑪𐑯𐑤𐑲𐑯,
𐑲 𐑣𐑴𐑐 𐑞𐑦𐑕 𐑢𐑦𐑤 𐑚𐑰𐑒𐑳𐑥 𐑩 𐑮𐑰𐑐𐑷𐑕𐑦𐑑𐑹𐑮𐑰 𐑓𐑹 ·𐑖𐑱𐑝𐑾𐑯 𐑦𐑯𐑓𐑹𐑥𐑱𐑖𐑳𐑯. 𐑕𐑴 𐑣𐑽'𐑕 𐑑 𐑞𐑦𐑕 𐑩𐑛𐑝𐑧𐑯𐑗𐑻!

:-) - ·𐑡𐑪𐑯

And here's what I think it says, given that:
- I've briefly skimmed over descriptions of Shavian letters
- I'm still shaky on some of the one-letter abbreviations — I recognize <NO> as <AT><NO><DAY> in either language, but I still haven't committed <TEA> to memory — it's <TEA><OOZE>, right?

(In-text parenthetical comments in brackets, as are "I-can't-figure-out-what-this-glyph-means" [?] markers.)

~ ~ ~

WELCOME [I figured this out from context. This establishes 𐑤 as the [l] sound, 𐑳 as [ə], and 𐑥 as [m].]
-------

[?]ello [oh, that upside-down ING must be for [h]] [?] welcome [OK, the 𐑯 all by itself must be [n] — "hello and welcome" is a common phrase] to [OK, these people must have their [t] sound be a stricter mirror of <DAY> than we do…] [what's that s-looking thing supposed to be, again? Oh, [m]…] m[?] Sh[?][?][?][what's…oh, [n]] al[?]ə[?]et we[?]s[?]t!

[OK, so what _did_ that sentence say?]

["Hello and welcome to something Shavian something-something."]

[At this point the blackletter analogy is looking strained, and a better one would be "an English speaker trying to read English text transliterated into Greek…and all the Greek they know they learned in college physics and chemistry classes."]

[Anyhow, moving on:]

[?] [this might be their <I>…] kl[?][?]ted […"collected"?] vis site to [?]lektis […huh?] writing and r[?]ding […oh, "reading"…] in v Sh[?] scri[?]t.

[OK, so that was probably…lessee…"Shaw Script" is something I've heard before, so…]

["I collected this site to ?lektis writing and reading in v Shaw script."]

~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~

At this point I still haven't quite figured out that their 𐑞 is our <THEY> — I still think it's <VIE>. It also hasn't quite sunk in that their lightning bolt (𐑰) is our <EAT>. And so on. This isn't like reading things set in Lucida Blackletter — it's like reading something written by someone who hasn't noticed that their normally QWERTY keyboard layout is set to Colemak.

For any Shavianists who'd like to have a crack at a similar task, I'd suggest having a look at http://adiabatic.github.io/qs-literature/call-of-cthulhu/ in a fairly modern browser. That said, the two blurbs of text aren't exactly equivalent — the shavian.weebly.com page uses common turns of phrase, whereas Lovecraft's writing style doesn't lead off that way.

Of course, I wouldn't be *too* surprised if someone weird enough to be interested in either Shavian or QS were able to recite the opening paragraph of anything Lovecraft verbatim with only minimal prompting, but I digress… ;)
